case_name: Deepak Trading Corporation v. the respondents

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 107 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 107 of 1961. Appeal

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 16, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 21 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 16, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 21 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant carrying on business in the name of Deepak Trading Corporation at Bulakhidas Building, Vithaldas Road, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was carrying on business in the name of Deepak Trading Corporation at Bulakhidas Building, Vithaldas Road, Bombay.

facts.text: On December 27, 1958, Sub Inspector of Police accompanied by Drug Inspector raided the said building.

anchor.surface_text: On December 27, 1958, the Sub Inspector of Police, accompanied by the Drug Inspector, raided the said building and

facts.text: Raiders found large quantities of absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze and other things in the building.

anchor.surface_text: found large quantities of absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze and other things. It was found that the

facts.text: Appellant was not only storing the goods but manufacturing them in Bombay and passing them off as manufactured by a firm in Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: appellant was not only storing these goods in large quantities but was actually manufacturing them in Bombay and passing them off as though they were manufactured by a firm of repute in Secunderabad.

facts.text: Samples of the articles and lint sent to Government Analyst.

anchor.surface_text: The samples of the aforesaid articles and lint were sent to the Government Analyst, who reported

facts.text: Government Analyst reported that lint was of standard quality and other articles were not of standard quality.

anchor.surface_text: that out of the samples sent to him only the lint was of standard quality and the other articles were not of standard quality.

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted before Presidency Magistrate, 16th Court Bombay, for offence under s.18 of the Act for manufacturing drugs not of standard quality.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was prosecuted before the Presidency Magistrate, 16th Court Bombay, for an offence under s. 18 of the Act, inter alia, for manufacturing drugs which were not of standard quality.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate acquitted appellant on ground that prosecution failed to prove possession.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Presidency. Magistrate acquitted the appellant on the ground that the prosecution had failed to prove that the articles were in the possession of the appellant.

facts.text: Bombay High Court reviewed evidence and found articles in possession of appellant, manufactured by him, and below standard.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a resurvey of the evidence came to a different conclusion and found that the said articles were not only found in the possession of the appellant but also were manufactured by him and that they were below the standard prescribed.

facts.text: Bombay High Court convicted appellant and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine of Rs. 500 under each count.

anchor.surface_text: On the finding, it convicted the. appellant and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/- under each count.

facts.text: Appeal argued on basis of facts found by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been argued on the basis of facts found by the High Court. The appellant was carrying

facts.text: Argument that articles not proved below standard was given up.

anchor.surface_text: Though an attempt was made to argue that the said articles had not been proved to be below the prescribed standard, it was subsequently given up

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 26, 1962 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 26. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by special leave

facts.text: High Court found this a gross case of large quantities of spurious drugs manufactured and passed off as goods of repute firm.

anchor.surface_text: When a similar argument was advanced in the High Court, it pointed out that this was a gross case where large quantities of spurious drugs had been manufactured by the appellant and passed off as goods manufactured by a firm of repute.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds articles are drugs within s.3(b) of the Act, agreeing with High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High. Court, that the said articles are substances used for or in the treatment within the meaning of s. 3 b  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds punishment lenient, no interference.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the punishment of rigorous imprisonment for three months was more lenient than severe. There is no case for interference with the sentences.

facts.text: Absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze are substances used for treatment in surgical cases.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed, and indeed it is not disputed, that absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages and gauze are substances within the meaning of the said expression.

facts.text: Possession of articles disputed at Magistrate level but found by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Presidency. Magistrate acquitted the appellant on the ground that the prosecution had failed to prove that the articles were in the possession of the appellant. The High Court on a resurvey of the evidence came to a different conclusion and found that the said articles were not only found in the possession of the appellant but also were manufactured by him
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 16, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 21 of 1961.
The appellant was prosecuted before the Presidency Magistrate, 16th Court Bombay, for an offence under s. 18 of the Act, inter alia, for manufacturing drugs which were not of standard quality.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to convict for manufacturing drugs not of standard quality.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: . appellant and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/

concepts.unlisted_description: Offence of manufacturing, storing or distributing drugs not of standard quality

anchor.surface_text: construction of s.3 b  of the Drugs Act, 1940, as amended by the Drugs Amendment Act, 1955, hereinafter called the Act.

The said section reads drug includes all medicines for internal or external use of human beings or animals and all substances intended to be used for or in the treatment mitigation or prevention of disease in human beings or animals other than medicines and substances exclusively used or prepared for use in accordance with the Ayur- vedic or Unani systems of medicine,

concepts.interpretation: Interpreted expansively to include not only medicines but 'substances' like surgical dressings (absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze) used for or in treatment, as they are essential aids in surgical cases to prevent substandard items defeating the Act's object.

concepts.interpretation: Articles (absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze) held to be 'drugs' as substances used for or in treatment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held agreeing with High Court that articles are substances used for or in the treatment within s.3(b).

arguments.claim: Surgical instruments would not fall within the definition of drug and gauze and lint fall within the same class

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel submitted that surgical instruments would not fall within the definition and that gauze and lint would fall within the same class.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dressing they are essential materials for treatment in surgical cases

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide if surgical instruments are drugs, but articles concerned are.

arguments.claim: Surgical dressings did not come under the purview of the Drugs Act as per expert committee report

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant sought to rely upon a report of a high powered committee consisting of expert doctors, who expressed the opinion in the report that as the surgical dressings did not come under the purview of the Drugs Act,

arguments.court_reasoning: Opinion of medical experts would not help in construing a statutory provision.

arguments.claim: Absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze are substances used for or in the treatment and hence drugs under s.3(b) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The said section reads drug includes all medicines for internal or external use of human beings or animals and all substances intended to be used for or in the treatment mitigation or prevention of disease in human beings or animals other than medicines and substances exclusively used or prepared for use in accordance with the Ayur- vedic or Unani systems of medicine,

arguments.court_reasoning: Punishment lenient for gross case of manufacturing large quantities of spurious drugs; no case for interference.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that the said articles are substances used for or in the treatment within the meaning of s. 3 b of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High. Court, that the said articles are substances used for or in the treatment within the meaning of s. 3 b  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expansive textual reading of 'substances intended to be used for or in the treatment' includes absorbent cotton wool, roller bandages, gauze as essential aids in surgical treatment; purposive construction upholds Act's object to prevent substandard drugs.

holdings.text: There is no case for interference with the sentences.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the punishment of rigorous imprisonment for three months was more lenient than severe. There is no case for interference with the sentences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sentence lenient considering gross anti-social act of manufacturing and passing off large quantities of spurious drugs as reputable firm's goods.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercase for interference with the sentences.

outcome.relief_summary: No interference with High Court conviction and sentence; upheld rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine of Rs. 500/- under each count
